A.name: A
A.articulation: open back unrounded vowel or open front unrounded vowel
A.description: The letter A in Swedish can be pronounced as either a long or short vowel.

B.name: B
B.description: The letter B represents the same sound as in English, a voiced bilabial stop.

C.name: C
C.articulation: voiceless velar stop or voiceless alveolar fricative
C.description: C is used in loanwords and foreign names, pronounced /k/ before hard vowels and /s/ before soft vowels.

D.name: D
D.description: D is pronounced as a voiced alveolar stop, similar to English.

E.name: E
E.articulation: close-mid front unrounded vowel or open-mid front unrounded vowel
E.description: The letter E can represent a long or short vowel sound, similar to 'ay' in 'say' or 'e' in 'bet'.

F.name: F
F.description: F is pronounced as a voiceless labiodental fricative, similar to English.

G.name: G
G.articulation: voiced velar stop or palatal approximant
G.description: G is pronounced /ɡ/ before hard vowels and /j/ before soft vowels.

H.name: H
H.description: H is pronounced as a voiceless glottal fricative, similar to English.

I.name: I
I.articulation: close front unrounded vowel or near-close near-front unrounded vowel
I.description: The letter I can be pronounced as a long or short vowel, similar to 'ee' in 'see' or 'i' in 'sit'.

J.name: J
J.description: J is pronounced as a palatal approximant, similar to 'y' in 'yes'.

K.name: K
K.articulation: voiceless velar stop or voiceless palato-alveolar fricative
K.description: K is pronounced /k/ before hard vowels and /ɕ/ before soft vowels.

L.name: L
L.description: L is pronounced as a voiced alveolar lateral approximant, similar to English.

M.name: M
M.description: M is pronounced as a voiced bilabial nasal, similar to English.

N.name: N
N.description: N is pronounced as a voiced alveolar nasal, similar to English.

O.name: O
O.articulation: close back rounded vowel or open-mid back rounded vowel
O.description: The letter O can represent a long or short vowel sound, similar to 'oo' in 'food' or 'o' in 'cot'.

P.name: P
P.description: P is pronounced as a voiceless bilabial stop, similar to English.

Q.name: Q
Q.description: Q is used in some loanwords and is pronounced as /k/.

R.name: R
R.description: R is typically pronounced as an alveolar trill.

S.name: S
S.description: S is pronounced as a voiceless alveolar fricative, similar to English.

T.name: T
T.description: T is pronounced as a voiceless alveolar stop, similar to English.

U.name: U
U.articulation: close central rounded vowel or close-mid front rounded vowel
U.description: U can represent a long or short vowel sound, unique to Swedish, pronounced with rounded lips.

V.name: V
V.description: V is pronounced as a voiced labiodental fricative, similar to English.

W.name: W
W.description: W is used in loanwords and is pronounced the same as V.

X.name: X
X.articulation: voiceless velar stop followed by voiceless alveolar fricative
X.description: X is used in loanwords and is pronounced as /ks/.

Y.name: Y
Y.articulation: close front rounded vowel or near-close near-front rounded vowel
Y.description: Y can represent a long or short vowel sound, pronounced with rounded lips.

Z.name: Z
Z.description: Z is used in loanwords and is pronounced as /s/.

Å.name: Å
Å.articulation: close-mid back rounded vowel or open-mid back rounded vowel
Å.description: Å is a unique Swedish letter representing a long or short vowel sound.

Ä.name: Ä
Ä.description: Ä represents a long or short vowel sound, similar to 'a' in 'care'.

Ö.name: Ö
Ö.articulation: close-mid front rounded vowel or open-mid front rounded vowel
Ö.description: Ö represents a long or short vowel sound, pronounced with rounded lips.
